text: Strasbourg Cathedral or the Cathedral of Our Lady of Strasbourg (, or Cathédrale de Strasbourg, or Straßburger Münster), also known as Strasbourg Minster, is a cathedral. The cathedral was built in Gothic style. The belltower is 142 m high. It was the highest building in the world from 1647 to 1874. It is currently the second-highest cathedral in France, after Rouen Cathedral, which is 9m higher, at 151m. In 1880, Cologne Cathedral was finished (157m), and later Ulm minster (at 161m), the highest Cathedral in the World. Considerable parts of it are still in Romanesque architecture. Nevertheless, it is widely considered to be among the finest examples of high, or late, Gothic architecture. Erwin von Steinbach is credited for major contributions from 1277 to his death in 1318. Victor Hugo described it as a "gigantic and delicate marvel"."Prodige du gigantesque et du délicat". Translation from a note at TrekEarth.com. The cathedral is visible far across the plains of Alsace and can be seen from as far off as the Vosges mountains or the Black Forest on the other side of the Rhine. An Al-Qaeda plot to bomb the adjacent Christmas market was prevented in 2000 by French and German police.France Convicts Islamic Militants - CBS.com Strassburg-Muenster-112-1987-gje.jpg Strassburg-Muenster-126-von Suedwest-2017-gje.jpg Strassburg-Muenster-114-Kraemergass-2005-gje.jpg Strassburg-Muenster-140-Westfassade-Hauptportal-2005-gje.jpg Strassburg- Muenster-154-Westfassade-Hauptportal-2017-gje.jpg Strassburg- Muenster-172-Westfassade-Hauptportal-Gewaendefiguren-2017-gje.jpg Strassburg- Muenster-312-zum Chor-2017-gje.jpg Baden-Baden-Steinbach-Meister-Erwin- Denkmal-14-2017-gje.jpg|Erwin von Steinbach in Baden-Baden == References == Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals Category:Cathedrals in France Category:Buildings and structures in Strasbourg Category:15th-century buildings and structures
